awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I: Development and Analysis of Functional NanoInks for Printed Neuromorphic Electronics and Smart Sensors
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project from Freescale LLC will be on scalable additive manufacturing of micro and macro scales for analog electronics, artificial intelligence (AI), and sensing applications. The project will leverage recent advancements in electrohydrodynamic and micro-transfer printing, alongside AI-controlled manufacturing, to produce micro and macro-scale electronic devices with a submicron resolution. The resulting devices will have the capability of computing and sensing, similar to biological brains. The project will strengthen domestic microelectronics innovation and production capabilities and support US leadership in AI and quantum computing. New intelligent systems developed using these techniques can help address challenges in healthcare, aerospace, defense, transportation, energy, and more.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project aims to demonstrate the manufacturing of
fully printed functional devices using an innovative multifunctional printing platform for next-generation electronics. The platform will provide development, optimization, and delivery of specialty inks with
conductive and semiconductive properties that will be printed on rigid and flexible surfaces to produce analog computing and sensing functionality. The platform will support printing at micro and macro scales, leveraging real-time feedback and artificial intelligence (AI) control for intelligent composition modification, delivery parameter optimization, and scalable manufacturing. Currently, conventional lithographic fabrication of functional devices is expensive and inefficient, as it requires complex supply chains, expensive hardware, and offshore production. This STTR project will combine precise inkjet printing for thin layer deposition and micro-transfer printing for large-area development to enable seamless fabrication of functional devices for sensing and analog computation in days instead of months, bypassing the complexities of modern silicon manufacturing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to develop and demonstrate a scalable approach for additively manufactured functional electronics. Traditional electronic device manufacturing relies on complex, costly, and energy-intensive lithographic processes, requiring extensive supply chains and offshore production. This effort focused on leveraging additive manufacturing techniques—including direct writing, electrohydrodynamic (EHD) printing, and micro-transfer printing—to fabricate functional electronic devices with minimal material waste using a single modular platform. To enhance precision and efficiency, machine learning (ML)-assisted manufacturing was integrated to enable real-time process optimization and defect assessment.

A major outcome of this project was the formulation and optimization of specialty conductive and memristive nanoinks for additive manufacturing. These inks were specifically designed for EHD, transfer printing, and direct writing techniques, allowing for precise control over electrical properties and device performance. A significant breakthrough was the development of a scale-free memristive ink, which exhibited consistent resistive switching properties independent of device geometry. This advancement has the potential to enable fully additive manufacturing of neuromorphic computing systems, which mimic biological brain function and provide a more efficient platform for artificial neural networks compared to conventional computing architectures. 

The project also demonstrated high-precision EHD printing to produce fully printed UV sensors and resistive switching synaptic channels using the scale-free memristive ink. The UV sensor exhibited rapid response and recovery times below 10 milliseconds, making it suitable for wearable electronics and real-time UV detection applications. Additionally, the printed synaptic channels showed stable switching behavior for over 10,000 cycles, comparable to commercial Flash memory. These findings highlight the potential of additively manufactured functional devices for flexible electronics, sensors, and neuromorphic computing, where miniaturization and customization are essential.

Another key innovation was the integration of real-time feedback and ML-driven process alignment into the manufacturing workflow. By utilizing computer vision and ML algorithms, the system enhanced alignment accuracy and dynamically adjusted printing parameters, ensuring greater consistency and higher production yields. This capability is critical for scaling up the production of specialty functional electronics, reducing defect rates, and enabling cost-effective manufacturing.

Beyond the technical achievements, this project generated industry interest from manufacturers in printed electronics, functional device development, and 3D printing technologies, addressing diverse markets, including wearable electronics, aerospace, medicine, and energy. Additionally, through a partnership with NC State University, this project has contributed to workforce development and public engagement in science and technology, fostering a skilled workforce for Industry 4.0.

This project's development of scale-free memristive ink represents a significant advancement in additive electronics manufacturing, enabling fully printed neuromorphic computing and sensing devices. By integrating this breakthrough with ML-driven additive manufacturing, the project establishes a foundation for scalable, lithography-free fabrication of next-generation high-precision microelectronics, strengthening U.S. competitiveness in neuromorphic computing, flexible electronics, and advanced sensing applications.


Last Modified: 02/17/2025
Modified by: Nikolay Frick
